posts.title: React2Shell CVE-2025-55182
posts.description:
Explained:

Critical RCE Vulnerability in React & Next.js.

Modern web development just faced its Log4Shell moment. On December 3, 2025, a critical security vulnerability in React Server Components (RSC) was publicly disclosed: üëâ CVE-2025‚Äì55182, nicknamed React2Shell, enables unauthenticated remote code execution (RCE) against servers running vulnerable React and Next.js applications ‚Äî with a CVSS score of 10.0, the highest possible severity. This bug allows attackers to execute arbitrary commands on servers with nothing more than a single crafted HTTP request ‚Äî no credentials, no special configuration, and no indicators by default.

Why This Is So Dangerous
React Server Components (introduced in React 19) allow rendering parts of a React application on the server for better performance and smaller client bundles.

However, the architecture depends on streaming serialized payloads over the ‚ÄúReact Flight‚Äù protocol ‚Äî and that‚Äôs exactly where things went wrong.

A flaw in deserialization logic allows malicious payloads to:

  • Manipulate JavaScript prototypes,

  • Resolve dangerous Node.js modules such as child_process,

  • Trigger functions capable of executing system commands.

The vulnerable path centers around a function called: requireModule()

The Reality: Exploitation Within Hours
This vulnerability didn‚Äôt sit unnoticed. Within hours of public disclosure, threat intelligence teams observed: Active exploitation China-aligned groups including: Earth Lamia AND Jackpot Panda began scanning and exploiting exposed RSC endpoints globally.

Captured attacks included:
  • Credential harvesting via dumping .env files.
  • Host reconnaissance using whoami, uname, id.
  • Persistence attempts by writing files under /tmp/.

Public proof-of-concept exploits were released on GitHub on December 4‚Äì5,achieving 100% success against clean default installs of create-next-app.
